+R @tgroh. Thanks Thomas.

I'll ask around a little and maybe move the larger discussion to the dev list. But it looks like [Pipeline / Jenkinsfile](https://jenkins.io/doc/book/pipeline/jenkinsfile/) is something along these lines.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/13681392/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/13681392)

Coverage increased (+1.0%) to 69.604% when pulling **cf022100f52183b68f59f731b59a75b3cda20895 on aaltay:combinefn** into **6dd90d89d3d324c9f9f8cb2b1faf38fe525f0a10 on apache:master**.

> One hack to avoid this would be to control this with a profile, which is not a fatal error if missing. The new toggle would be --activate-profiles '!python-container'. That is not a good long-term solution because poms are gross enough with hacks kept to a minimum.
We could also remove the --also-make-dependents since I think the Python SDKs model of including all code in a single module makes it irrelevant. My experience trying to run build all submodules, as with --projects runners is that it does not build submodules by default, so you can build --projects sdks/python and it will not automatically build the submodule.

It sounds like these hacks would silence the problem but it can still manifest in a different context down the road. If we consider hacks for the sake of this release branch, I would cherrypick 38a9cdb08f3d682f7c0d32aadbc645a34dd56639 into the branch, which adds sdks/python/containers/pom.xml and presumably will make Jenkins happy. And then we should figure out a long-term solution that uses job configs from the branch for Jenkins presubmit runs for the branch. Filed: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-3047.

> The alternative (ignoring the results) is not viable because tests fails early on without executing anything else. 

I ran locally in the brach directory the following commands. Does this gives us enough confidence that this PR is safe to merge?
```
mvn clean install -pl sdks/python -am -amd 
mvn clean install -pl sdks/java/core,runners/direct-java -am -amd
```
Both runs were successful and finished within 4 and 20 min respectively. Jenkins runs take around an hour.
There were real failures, I believe caused by bugs in the Dataflow worker, but also the Jenkins worker ran out of ability to launch threads.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/13681945/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/13681945)

Coverage increased (+1.0%) to 69.611% when pulling **efd05feb083b70a5b22d278282a9488b459027bb on kennknowles:valueInEmptyWindows** into **8e1caea64f3e303a5b711ba8f50952cb5af9253a on apache:master**.

My mistake for misreading the Jenkins logs, so ignoring the error is indeed not a good alternative.

+1 to @tvalentyn's proposal of cherrypicking the container commit he mentions. It is safe (adds only the python container code, which is not part of the release anyway and to be ignored by the test) and fixes the problem, so it seems to be the simplest and fastest way forward for the 2.2.0 release.

I was not able to cherrypick 38a9cdb since I could not find it on any branch, including herohde/containers. 38a9cdb is a subset of 79c55db, so I cherrypicked 79c55db and manually reverted eeb4d73 which is also a part of  79c55db, in case it matters. I am curious if there is a way to cherrypick a subset of commits from a PR merged into another branch.
@jkff: can you please take another look?
The commits were squashed while merging, that is why you can only find one of them. Current changes on this PR looks correct to me.
Thank you @kennknowles. I missed #3941. I will revert the bundle_processor changes here.
R: @tgroh
Do we need this change in the release branch in order to support python streaming on dataflow with the 2.2.0 release?

Cherrypicking a commit is independent of whether it is on any branch. The problem is likely that your `git fetch` did not pull it down because it was not reachable from any public tag or branch, or that it was garbage collected. GitHub is pretty aggressive about GC so it must be referenced somewhere...
Side note - if changes in a PR have reasonable meaning and can stand alone, they shouldn't be squashed. Our contribution guide is a bit contrary to best practice in this regard.

Yeah, yeah, I know. Not super-duper happy with the name, but it's the lingo
I've heard plenty of. If you have a better idea (fn-api-java-core or
something?) I'm happy to get to a rename.

PipelineOptions is our injection mechanism and commonly used within tests/code to override how things work. Attempting to only move out the single parameter would be inconsistent with how the majority of the system passes around information so it would be best if it was left alone or the majority was modified to perform injection another way.

R: @scwhittle we discussed that there was some complexity around multiplexing EOW and GC timers and holds over the same tag - hence this bug - but also that the way ReduceFnRunner owns EOW is obsolete and a bug
CC: @dpmills @bjchambers

The volume of the change is largely because `ReduceFnRunnerTest` has a lot of sanity checking along the way that is independent of the output we expect, as well as a lot of mocks that required further specification to reflect real behaviors that we were testing.

In the latest run Python tests failed again with:

CalledProcessError: Command '['pip', 'install', '--target', '/home/jenkins/jenkins-slave/workspace/beam_PreCommit_Python_MavenInstall/sdks/python/.eggs/grpcio-wheels', '--build', '/home/jenkins/jenkins-slave/workspace/beam_PreCommit_Python_MavenInstall/sdks/python/.eggs/grpcio-wheels-build', '--upgrade', 'grpcio-tools>=1.3.5']' returned non-zero exit status 1
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "setup.py", line 203, in <module>
    'test': generate_protos_first(test),
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/distutils/core.py", line 151, in setup
    dist.run_commands()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/distutils/dist.py", line 953, in run_commands
    self.run_command(cmd)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/distutils/dist.py", line 972, in run_command
    cmd_obj.run()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/distutils/command/build.py", line 128, in run
    self.run_command(cmd_name)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/distutils/cmd.py", line 326, in run_command
    self.distribution.run_command(command)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/distutils/dist.py", line 972, in run_command
    cmd_obj.run()
  File "setup.py", line 143, in run
    gen_protos.generate_proto_files()
  File "/home/jenkins/jenkins-slave/workspace/beam_PreCommit_Python_MavenInstall/sdks/python/gen_protos.py", line 86, in generate_proto_files
    raise ValueError("Proto generation failed (see log for details).")
ValueError: Proto generation failed (see log for details).

Suspecting Jenkins may be using sdks/python/gen_protos.py version updated by this PR https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/3924.

We already have `DataflowRunner.fromOptions(...)`. Hanging on to the options was a design mistake. The runner should not depend on unbounded global (and mutable!) state, but should pull out just the pieces it needs for instantiation. I didn't do it here anyhow.

Java suite keeps failing with "Maven JVM terminated unexpectedly with exit code 137".
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/24989653/jenkins-maven-build-137-error suggests the machine running Jenkins may be running out of virtual memory. @jasonkuster Is there something we should do about this?

Given current test infrastructure is not using correct source files, and Python tests past locally, I'm going to stop investigating test failures on this PR. Ahmet, do you feel comfortable merging it in the current state?
run java precommit
Can we get the logged details? FWIW I also essentially always get a failure there unless I run it in a virtualenv. Presumably something about my system installs.
The `gen_protos.py` has not been changed for this branch, and Jenkins doesn't do anything with them.
Thank you!

We have avoided using dependency injection and copying forward all dependencies including our dependencies dependencies and so forth is a pain and having many context objects or a god object is a pain and not much better for scoping other then PipelineOptions. Best suggestion (without any implementation traction) was to add support for PipelineOptions to become "immutable".

Looks like the error is a flake, since Python tests just passed.

gen_protos.py runs `pip install command` https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/9c2a6e771d30e3e120b941bd2d450a00d8b7f091/sdks/python/gen_protos.py#L122

Then something goes wrong:
Temp directory GC'ed? Never created?

> writing list of installed files to '/tmp/pip-UOKO_n-record/install-record.txt'
> error: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/tmp/pip-UOKO_n-record/install-record.txt'

Then pip attempts to clean up temp directory, also fails:
> Exception:
> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/basecommand.py", line 122, in main
>     status = self.run(options, args)
>  ...
>   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/req.py", line 751, in install
>     os.rmdir(temp_location)
> OSError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/tmp/pip-UOKO_n-record'

Then pip fails to join a list of string being unable to perform byte encoding. Unexpected symbols happen to be in the log message? Or memory corruption?

> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "/usr/bin/pip", line 9, in <module>
>     load_entry_point('pip==1.5.4', 'console_scripts', 'pip')()
>   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/__init__.py", line 235, in main
>     return command.main(cmd_args)
>   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/basecommand.py", line 161, in main
>     text = '\n'.join(complete_log)

> UnicodeDecodeError:`
 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xe2 in position 42: ordinal not in range(128)

This is the full log https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PreCommit_Python_MavenInstall/228/consoleFull

Changes Unknown when pulling **a4e36ef94c4f7a26c96e424c18408b5ae42ca16d on aaltay:label** into ** on apache:master**.

@jkff - Has Dataflow always created Datasets/Tables in BigQuery? I've never seen it do that before, and I always through it exported tables/queries to GCS for reading into the pipeline. The issue we are now seeing is that our Dataflow pipelines share the same project id as our BigQuery users.

So, these temp datasets/tables are now showing up in their web UI. Our BigQuery users know nothing about Dataflow and the pipelines we run behind the scenes for them - they just ETL the data in and out of BigQuery. It's abstracted from the BigQuery users.

We've had several users contact us asking why they suddenly see these weird looking datasets and tables in the BigQuery Web UI e.g:

![screen shot 2017-10-09 at 5 06 15 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5554342/31530787-77e96922-b02e-11e7-8cf6-28aa24d87211.png)

This is not a good experience for our BQ users.

Also, what if a batch pipeline takes more than 24hrs? We've had batch pipelines run close to that due to sheer volume of data its ingesting and writing.

Cheers,
Graham

`getDatabaseClient` client is called in a method marked with `@Setup` annotation. I suspect it could be shared between multiple bundles. Verifying the number of times it gets called could cause flakiness, removed the check.

Looks good once Eugene's comments are addressed.

Yes, I believe dataflow always created temporary datasets when reading from
a query (except perhaps in some versions before 2.0? I'm not sure but I
don't think so, because Bigquery doesn't have a feature to directly export
results of a large query to files). Query results are exported to a
dataset, then the dataset is exported to files and the dataset is deleted,
then the job processes the files and the files are deleted at some point.
